ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Andy, The patterns that may be discovered by CPPNs (you shouldn t mention HyperNEAT explicitly since it is based on the CPPN theory) depend only of what set

Hi Andy, 

The patterns that may be discovered by CPPNs (you shouldn't ment=
ion 
HyperNEAT explicitly since it is based on the CPPN theory) depend 
onl=
y of what set of canonical activation functions you choose. And 
CPPNs show=
ed that they are capable of representing all known patterns 
from nature/bi=
ology, symettry, imperfect symettry, repetition, and 
repetition with varia=
tion. Combining CPPN evolution with NEAT (CPPN-
NEAT) introduces another im=
portant component, that is, the 
elaboration of preevolved structure, i.e. =
complexification. Well just 
play around in the PicBreeder site and you wil=
l get a feeling of what 
is possible. You can easily imagine (extrapolate) =
those pictures as 
if they were connectivity concepts of neural networks. W=
hy do you 
need a benchmark at all? It was discussed that the selection pro=
cess 
is the most important thing for discovering certain types of 
pattern=
s. It is even more natural in some sense. In fact I've seen 
that a segment=
ed picture can be turned into a circle-like picture 
just by selecting the =
roundest individuals. So in fact the dynamics 
of evolution guide the proce=
ss. 

About the computational cost, I think you can see it for yourself. It=
 
is clear that CPPN-based phenotypes need a lot of time to create, 
since =
the CPPN is requeried many times and each query is a couple of 
NN activati=
ons until relaxation. In fact for some tasks the creation 
of the phenotype=
s takes more time than evaluating them, but this is 
always domain dependan=
t. 

As I see you want this.. "data".. written and exposed as a separate 
e=
xperiment in the papers from the Eplex group but it is so obvious 
that you=
 just need to think about it for a second and answer 
yourself. 

Peter

--=
